addressleaf.section:
To the right honorable my singular good Lord
e L. Burghley, Lord high Treasuro
r
of England

23 F
b
1589
M
r
Bodelie to my L.
Takinge of
Breda
./.

page.lettertext:
It may please yo
r
L. to be advertised
that wheras in a former of
e 21 herof
I have certified yo
r
L. of an enterprise
towardes upp
o
e towne of Breda, we
have newes at this instant,
at
e towne is
taken. I doe not doubt but it is adver-
tised home, by
e
Governo
r
of Berghen
, or
some others
at are neere, and have readier
meanes to convey their letters. Nevertheles
for
e more assurance, I thought it my duty
to signifie somwhat, uppon
e fitte opportunitie
of a speedy messenger, who hath brought us
e tidinges, and is presently uppon it, to
depart for
Zeland
. The
Councell of
state
hath no perfitt intelligence as yet
of many speciall circumstances, which yo
r
L. might require. But
e
Count
hath written
in generall,
at
e exploit was perfourmed
by
Cap
t
Harengieres
a Wallon, w
t
80
souldiers, w
ch
were cunningly conveied and
covered w
t
turfe in a flatte bottom boate
of 30 Last, and conducted into e Castel
by a certain Water man, an old servant
of
e late
Prince of Orenge
, and one that
usually served
e Castell w
t
turfe. They
entred in w
t
e boate,
e 21 of this moneth
about 2 of
e clocke in
e after noone, and
continued quietly till midnight: at whiche
time
ei issued fourth, assaulted 2
corps
de Guarde
, and slue some 30 persons,
w
t
out
e losse of any one of o
rs
. The Count
being then at
Williamstat
, uppon intelligence
that
e Castell was possessed, marched w
t
fol.136v
all his troupes towardes
e castell, where he
entred about 5 of
e clocke
e next morning.
Uppon whose comming 6 companies of Italians
which were w
t
in
e towne, fledde away, and
the burgesses presently yelded, compounding
w
t
e Count for 2 monethes pay to
e souldiers.
We looke every houre for more particularities,
w
t
w
ch
I will acquaint y o
r
L. in my next,
w
t
humble request, to be excused for my hast
in this,
and so I take my humble leave.
Fr
o
e
Hage
. Fe
b
23. 89
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley
